Listing goal: Aggregate zone
Notes: Single lookup that contains results from black, exploit and policy lists

Listing goal: Lists individual IP addresses that have sent mail to spam traps, and some manually-added address blocks.
Nomination: Mostly automatic with some manual additions
Listing lifetime: For automated, listings 5.6 days after last event. Manual additions are permanent.

Listing goal: Lists IP addresses behaving in a way that indicates they are compromised, infected, proxies, or VPN or TOR exit nodes.
Lists IP addresses that should not be connecting directly to MX, such as residential IP addresses etc.
Notes: Lists ranges that have generic or templated rDNS. Individual IP addresses can be delisted immediately via web.

Listing goal: Lists domains seen in spam hitting traps.
Notes: Can be used as an RHSBL and a URIBL.

Listing goal: Lists domains that are newly observed (first use).
Notes: Based on historical passive DNS data, lists domains first seen in the wild within the last 25 hours).

Listing goal: Lists short URLs (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
Notes: Created to handle popular shorteners that are misused to hide domains from blacklisting

Listing goal: Lists URLs of online drive services (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
Notes: Current only listing Google Drive and Yandex Disk URLs that are used to avoid domain blacklisting.

Listing goal: Extremely conservative list of single IP4 addresses that produce exclusively spam/malware as indicated by the GBUdb IP Reputation system. Most systems should be able to safely reject connections based on this list.
Nomination: Automatic: IP addresses are added when the GBUdb "cloud" statistics reach a probability figure that indicates 95% of messages produce a spam/malware pattern match and a confidence figure that indicates sufficient data to trust the probability data.
Listing lifetime: Automatic: Continuous while reputation statistics remain bad. Warning: Produces false positives, and has no remedy/removal process. IP addresses are dropped quickly if the statistics improve (within an hour). IP addresses are dropped within 36 hours (typ) if no more messages are seen (dead zombie).
Notes: Source data is derived from a global network of Message Sniffer[1] filtering nodes in real-time. Truncate data is updated from statistics every 10 minutes. Warning: Unreliable, as it produces false positives. It is impossible to find additional information or to manually troubleshoot the problem. It is based on results created by their proprietary software running a proprietary algorithm.

Listing goal: Single IP4 addresses that produce exclusively spam or malware. Mail service providers are protected.
Listing lifetime: Last activities after one year automatic or delist request by mail spam@metunet.com.tr
Notes: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: IP4 / IPv6 addresses that produce spam or malware.
Listing lifetime: List is updated daily. Reputation is gradually restored after days of good / null activity
Notes: Immediate delisting via the website

Listing goal: Single IP addresses which only send UBE. Specializing in snowshoe spam and other 'under the radar' spam which evades many other DNSBLs. Has FP-level comparable to Zen.
Nomination: Automatic (upon receipt of spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Typically an automatic expiration 11 days after the last abuse was seen, but with some exceptions
Notes: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Lists /24 blocks of IP addresses which usually only send UBE and containing at least several addresses which are confirmed emitters of junk mail. Collateral listings are kept to a minimum because subsections are often carved from /24 listings when spammers and legit senders share the same /24 block.
Nomination: Automatic once at least several IP addresses from a given block are individually listed on ivmSIP, with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Expiration time increases to many weeks as the fraction of IP addresses in the /24 block in question sending junk mail increases.
Notes: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Comparable to uribl.com and surbl.org, this is a list of IP addresses and domains which are used by spammers in the clickable links found in the body of spam messages
Nomination: Automatic (upon receipt of spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Typically an automatic expiration several weeks after the last abuse was seen
Notes: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial e-mail senders
Notes: SORBS , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial e-mail senders
Notes: "Safe" Aggregate zone (all zones in dnsbl.sorbs.net except "recent", "old", "spam" and "escalations")

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: HTTP , URL: /wiki/HTTP

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: SOCKS , URL: /wiki/SOCKS

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Additional proxy servers
Notes: Those not already listed in the HTTP or SOCKS databases

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: SMTP , URL: /wiki/SMTP

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: FormMail , URL: /wiki/FormMail
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested or automated expiry

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the SORBS spam traps or administrators in the last 48 hours
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the SORBS spam traps or administrators in the last 28 days
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hosts that have sent spam to the SORBS spam traps or administrators in the last year
Listing lifetime: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hosts that have allegedly sent spam to the SORBS spam traps or administrators ever

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Address blocks of service providers believed to support spammers
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested and matter resolved
Notes: Service providers are added on receipt of a 'third strike' spam

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hosts demanding that they never be tested

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Hijacked networks

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Dynamic IP address ranges
Notes: Not a list of dial-up IP addresses

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy
Notes: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Aggregate RHS zones

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: DNS , URL: /wiki/Domain_name_system
Nomination: Open submission via automated testing page

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System , URL: /wiki/Spam_and_Open_Relay_Blocking_System
Listing goal: Domains which the owners have confirmed will not be used for sending mail
This list contains IP addresses that are observed to be involved in sending spam, snowshoe spamming, botnet command and controllers (C&Cs), bulletproof hosting companies and hijacked address space.
Listing lifetime: From five minutes to a year or more, depending on issue and resolution

Listing goal: This lists the individual IPv4 addresses (/32s) that are infected with malware, worms, and Trojans; third party exploits, such as open proxies; or devices controlled by botnets. The constantly updated list is designed to protect networks from malware and spam by preventing mailservers from accepting connections from compromised computing devices.
Notes: Composite Blocking List , URL: /wiki/Composite_Blocking_List

Listing goal: This list is a real-time database of raw and filtered feeds that provides additional information on hijacked IP addresses. The eXBL is available to selected security organizations and cyber incident response teams.
Notes: Composite Blocking List , URL: /wiki/Composite_Blocking_List

Listing goal: Domains owned by spammers and used for spam or other malicious purposes. This blocklist also contains domains owned by non-spammers which are used for legitimate purposes, but have been hijacked by spammers.
Nomination: Ranking of over 80 different metrics and machine learning
Listing lifetime: A few days, with self-removal generally allowed

Listing goal: This list provides detailed information on each domain listing and is available via an API. This enables querying of the DBL engine, returning a JSON record for each domain. The Enhanced Domain Blocklist (eDBL) can be used to track a particular domain's score over a longer period, or to combine Domain Blocklist data with other information.
Listing lifetime: A few days. Self-removal generally allowed.

Listing goal: This list includes IP address ranges for end-user devices, such as home routers, smart TVs, and other Information of Things (IoT) devices, from which mail should never be sent. This protects networks from the potential of being compromised by malware spread by botnet command and controller servers (C&Cs).
Nomination: Manual, by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team
Notes: Should not be confused with the MAPS DUL and Wirehub Dynablocker lists

Listing goal: This list contains the following content areas: Cryptowallet (Bitcoin etc.), malware and e-mail addresses. Hash Blocklists (HBL) are lists of cryptographic hashes associated with malicious content, as opposed to IP addresses or domains. They are extremely useful for filtering fraudulent mail coming from ISPs, domains, or IP addresses that Spamhaus is unable to list e.g. Gmail. Additionally, they can block mail containing malware files.
Nomination: Manual, by providers controlling the addresses or by Spamhaus PBL Team

Listing goal: This lists newly registered domains for 24 hours. Domains that have just been registered are rarely used by legitimate organizations immediately. Cybercriminals register and burn 100s of domains daily. The Zero Reputation Domain (ZRD) blocklist helps to protect users from following links and visiting newly registered domains until it is established that they are not associated with zero day attacks; phishing, bot-herding, spyware or ransomware campaigns.
A single lookup for querying the SBL, XBL and PBL databases
Notes: Preferred list to check all Spamhaus address lists with one query
This DNSBL zone is part of the default configuration for Proventia Mail Security System and Lotus Protector for Mail Security

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to trap
Notes: Sending a special mail generated using the removalform contains the listed IP in the mailheader.

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to trap
IP addresses used to send UBE to members
IP addresses which have been used to transmit reported mail to SpamCop users
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops, has self removal

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISPs using MagicMail Servers, with no reverse DNS service
Listing lifetime: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS configured

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISPs using MagicMail Servers, with non-conforming reverse DNS service (See Best Practises) indicative of compromised systems
Listing lifetime: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS set to conform to Best Practises

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISPs using MagicMail Servers, and manually confirmed as spam sources
IP addresses detected probing passwords or authenticating without sending mail
Detects viruses by behavior using fake high MX and tracking non-use of QUIT
Listing lifetime: Black list entries last 4 days. White list entries last 10 days.

Blacklist operator: Heise Zeitschriften Verlag GmbH & Co. KG, hosted by manitu GmbH
Listing goal: Lists single IP addresses (no address ranges) that send spam to spam traps. Lists mailhosts, rather than domains, and thus blocks entire hosting providers and ISPs.
Nomination: Automated listing due to spam trap hits. Exceptions apply to bounces, NDRs and whitelisted IP addresses.
Listing lifetime: 12 hours after last listing or until self delisting
Notes: fuzzy checksum , URL: /wiki/Fuzzy_checksum

Listing goal: IP addresses used to in attacks over SSH, IMAP, SMTP, FTP, or HTTP, or for attacks involving remote file inclusion, SQL injection, or DDOS
Nomination: Automatic: over honeypots and with over 515 users and 630 servers from blocklist.de via Fail2Ban or own scripts
Listing lifetime: Automatic: 48 Hours after the last Attack. But earlier remove is available over the Delist-Link
Notes: Services are free. Source data is from Honeypot-Systems and over 515 User with 630 Servern there reports Attacks with Fail2Ban

Listing goal: Spam sources from mail, forums, referrer spam and dictionary attacks
Listing lifetime: Twelve months unless ISPs request removal earlier
Notes: By request. ISPs can provide request exclusion.

Listing goal: Spam Trap
Nomination: List of IP addresses that sends spam or causing troubles with botnets or phishing
Notes: Removal requests will be investigated and processed within 24 hours of submission. Previously known as IPrange.net RBL Project

Listing goal: Collection of Bad Actors from various sources, Works great with PiHole for personal use.
Nomination: Spammers, Scammers, Malware, Cryptominers, TOR, botnets, phishing, attackers, harvesters, exfiltration etc. Basically anything and everything "bad"
Notes: Removal requests will be investigated. Contact details provided.

Listing goal: Spam Trap
Nomination: Provides a list of IP addresses which are sending spam. The Barracuda Reputation system uses automated collection methods to add and delete IP addresses from the BRBL.
Notes: Requires registration of administrator and hosts to use. Removal requests are typically investigated and processed within 12 hours of submission if provided with a valid explanation.

Listing goal: Bad reputation, difficult to identify the responsible, dynamic addresses, SLAAC flag without genuine mail service and inappropriate use of the URL
Nomination: Provides a list of IPv4/IPv6 addresses and domains which are sending spam or phishing.
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested or seven days with good reputation
Notes: Feedback , URL: https://spfbl.net/en/feedback

Listing goal: IP addresses which have sent mail to addresses harvested from suppression (opt-out) files
Listing lifetime: For 30 days after last offending message unless removal is requested

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as unsolicited bulk/commercial e-mail senders, Web spam
Notes: Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Unsolicited bulk/commercial e-mail senders, Web spam
Notes: Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Spam traps
Nomination: A single IP address (127.0.0.#) is listed upon sending spam to a spam trap. Sending from multiple addresses within a range within a short period of time will result in a class C listing (127.0.#.0).
Listing lifetime: Until an address owner/authorized administrator requests listing removal
Notes: Single address Listed with Data result 127.0.0.# Class C address block listed with data result 127.0.#.0 Codes are as follows: (ie. General spam single address result 127.0.0.1) General spam, sending spam to 0Spam Project spam traps Removal request made but missing required information Does not follow valid can-spam rules for mail lists RFC-non-compliant, server errors or improper configuration Repeat offenders (IP addresses that have been removed and listed again three or more times in a short period) Bouncing mail to the wrong server, RFC-non-compliant configurations Mail relay with reports of spam Bouncing spoofed-sender mail Fraud or scam mail, malware or illegal or abusive content

Listing goal: Addresses and domains for junk mail filtering (aggregate zone)
Nomination: Mostly automatic with some manual additions

Listing goal: Single IP4 addresses produce exclusively spam or malware. Respective Mail providers protected like Free and paid mail providers.
Listing lifetime: One year after last activity (automatic) or delist request by mail
Notes: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Botnet IP list. Single IPv4 addresses produced from spam, pure bots. No mail server addresses.
Notes: RSPAMD , URL: https://rspamd.com/

Listing goal: BAD senders list. Single IPv4 addresses with high spam rate. Mostly botnets and large spammers. Also, mail servers which send malware are listed.
